column3: Empty bare barren dead space. The monument remains. Almost all shops have long been closed. Nothing more to see.

column2: Iconic Landmark - Crossroads of the World, LA
column3: We drove by and I took a photo of the Crossroads of the World. its an iconic landmark which was designed by Robert V. Derrah and initially opened in 1936. Originally it was a open market and popular. Now it has been converted to an office building. It is in the Hollywood Area.

column2: You can't actually do anything here
column3: It was behind locked gates the day I visited, but regardless you aren't really supposed to go and visit, it's not an attraction so much as a bunch of offices and they don't encourage loitering. The reason for my visit was to see the iconic "Crossroads of the World" sign, made famous from its depiction on the back of the 1975 album "America's Greatest Hits". Once I saw it, I was done.

column2: Had an appointment hereIt was okay (both the building and the appointment). Has most definitely seen much better days.
column3: Had an appointment here. The experience was okay. (Appointment and building). Would love to see the building cleaned up; it has definitely seen better days.
This art deco/fun architecture type complex has seen better days. most of the buildings are occupied offices. If you're intested in buildings with history, make a quck stop here.
